node.title: Inflation will clobber "entitled generation," BlackRock exec says
node.description: "We have a very entitled generation that has never had to sacrifice," Rob Kapito reportedly said at an oil and gas conference.
node.content: ["It's been at least 40 years since inflation was as high as it is today, and that means an entire generation of \"entitled\" consumers is about to learn some very rude lessons about life and money, according to BlackRock President Rob Kapito.", "Kapito, who is also co-founder of BlackRock, the world's largest investor of other people's money, spoke this week at a conference of oil and gas producers in Austin, Texas. ", "\"For the first time, this generation is going to go into a store and not be able to get what they want,\" Kapito said, according to Bloomberg News.\u00a0", "\"And we have a very entitled generation that has never had to sacrifice,\" he said, according to the outlet.", "BlackRock has about $10 trillion of clients' assets under management. As its president, Kapito made $22 million last year, putting him in the top one-tenth of the richest\u00a0one percent of Americans.", "According to Kapito's comments, the economy is dealing with \"scarcity inflation,\" which are shortages of commodities, housing and workers. \"I would put on your seat belts because this is something that we haven't seen,\" Kapito said, according to Bloomberg.", "Consumer prices are rising at nearly 8% year-over-year, the fastest rate since the early 1980s. Supply-chain disruptions during the coronavirus pandemic first led to price jumps for big-ticket items like cars, electronics and furniture. Those price hikes then spread throughout the economy as companies felt empowered to pass on higher costs. ", "Russia's invasion of Ukraine is likely to keep prices high in the near term, BlackRock CEO and co-founder Larry Fink warned investors last week.", "\"Central banks \u2026 face a dilemma they haven't faced in decades, which has been worsened by geopolitical conflict and the resulting energy shocks,\" Fink wrote. \"Central banks must choose whether to live with higher inflation or slow economic activity and employment to lower inflation quickly.\"\u00a0", "Kapito's \"entitled generation\" comments this week drew swift backlash on social media, where many commenters pointed out that younger workers are much poorer than previous generations\u00a0were at their age and face higher debt, more unstable work and a potentially unlivable future with climate change.\u00a0", "\"Ah yes. The entitled generation that has suffered thru a global recession that saw entire countries default, wars, a pandemic and a 'once in a lifetime' climate catastrophe every 3 years. The generation [whose] wages stagnate, job security down, while [cost of living] goes up,\" one user\u00a0said on Twitter. \"That generation?\""]
